ai.summary: The Antrim Hills Way is a demanding long-distance hike in the UK, totaling about 34.1 km. The route traverses exposed uplands and rugged trails, requiring solid fitness, navigation, and suitable gear. Expect variable weather, boggy sections, and potentially steep climbs.
ai.terrain_summary: Rugged upland moorland with grassy ridges, peat bogs, rocky outcrops, and muddy tracks. Open exposure means wind and sudden weather changes can affect visibility and comfort; navigation can be challenging in low visibility sections.
ai.safety_notes: This is a hard, long hike. Plan for a full day or split the route into stages. Check weather forecasts and be prepared for rapid changes. Carry a detailed map and compass (or a reliable GPS) and know how to use them. Do not rely solely on mobile phones. Tell someone your plan and expected return. Bring sufficient clothing, extra layers, waterproofs, and head protection. Stay on marked paths where possible, monitor footing on boggy sections, and turn back if signs of severe weather or exhaustion appear. Consider an exit point or shorter alternative if you are unsure of conditions.
recommended_gear: Map and compass or GPS device
Personal locator beacon or phone with offline maps (if available)
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly March–October) typically offers milder weather, longer daylight, and easier navigation. Winter hiking can bring snow, ice, and high winds; only for experienced hikers with specialized equipment.

seo.title: Antrim Hills Way – 34.1 km Hard Hike in the UK
seo.meta_description: Explore the challenging Antrim Hills Way, a 34.1 km long-distance trail in the UK. Learn about terrain, safety considerations, best seasons, and gear recommendations.
